trans-unit.target: The Digital Archive of Japan's 2011 Disasters
is an evolving, collaborative space for citizens, researchers and policy makers, and a site of shared memory for those most directly affected by these events.
The Digital Archive of Japan's 2011 Disasters' core missions
to index, preserve and make widely accessible the digital records of the events of March 2011 and their aftermath
to provide a public space of information sharing, collaboration and conversation for citizens, researchers and policy makers
to serve as a site of shared memory for those most affected by these events and most concerned about their consequences

The archive aims to foster new connections, both between items and among users. As they move from item to item and collection to collection users encounter an ever-expanding network of fellow archivists, from the major organization that submits thousands of location- and direction-tagged photographs to the fellow citizen who submits her family's testimonial to the historian who seeks to understand the interaction of public and private actors in the relief effort.
Browse, annotate and visualize digital records
Contribute reports, photos, videos, links, etc.

The archive is not limited to simple search of materials. In addition to user collections, there is also a map that visualizes all materials that are tagged with geographic information, especially tweets. The archive also actively solicits user submissions of resources such as Web sites, and user testimonials about personal experiences of the disasters and their aftermath. Thus, the archive is an interactive space encouraging, and indeed thriving on, user participation.
The archive is currently in development and only available to partners.

This 'beta' version of the Digital Archive of Japan's 2011 Disasters is still a work in progress. We invite you to look around and see what's going on, but there will be a few bumps in the road. We're working every day to expand the functionality of the site and fix bugs. We hope you you are able to make use of the site and keep checking back!
Hold Shift and Drag in order to create a box around the area you would like to search
This public collection assembles visual and textual records documenting the impacts of the March 11, 2011 disasters on fisheries and mariculture in Minami Sanriku-chō and nearby Kesennuma.
This public collection features articles, plans, and images related to the pivotal discussions taking place among residents of disaster-stricken areas over their economic future and how to rebuild.
This public collection assembles records related to public concerns over radioactive food contamination and the future of regional agriculture since the 2011 Fukushima nuclear catastrophe.

The website is still in beta and we need your help to make it better! Please share your feedback and if something is not working properly, please write us a brief description of what's wrong. You can also reach us at info [at] jdarchive.org
a link to the current view will be included automatically
Drag items here to add to your collection
Enter your keyword search in the box to the left.
To search only tags, begin your search with "t" and select "tag:"
To search by user, begin your search with "u" and select "user:"

This beta version of the Digital Archive of Japan's 2011 Disasters is the result of an ongoing global collaborative effort. Its ever-expanding content represents the contributions of an array of individuals and organizations variously affected by the unprecedented events of March 2011 and their aftermath. The development of the archive interface has been led by the Edwin O. Reischauer Institute at Harvard University in collaboration with metaLAB (at) Harvard, Harvard's Center for Geographic Analysis and Zeega.org, a non-profit creative technology company. This current version lays the groundwork for an ever-evolving and ultimately participatory archive. The interface is built using Zeega, an open-source platform that supports initaitives in crisis archiving, enabling anyone to create participatory projects that combine original content with photos, videos, text, audio, data feeds and maps via APIs from across the web.
Are you sure you want to remove this item from the collection?
Sorry, the map view doesn't support this yet.

The Japan Digital Archive is currently optimized for the latest versions of Chrome, Internet Explorer, Firefox and Safari. Please upgrade your browser to best experience the Japan Digital Archive
Note: it may take several minutes for the changes to take effect
Anyone can view your collection. Your collection will appear in general archive searches.
Only those people with a link to your collection can view it. Your collection will not appear in general archive searches or on your public user page.
Will not show up in search results

We need your help finding websites to archive! Please fill out the form below as thoroughly as possible.
* Required Field
Search to designate a location that this website is primarily about. Move the point if necessary.

Please enter as much information as you feel comfortable with in the fields below.
* Required Field
Please list the locations about which you are writing. Search for or directly move the pin to each location. You may optionally give each location a specific name.

Do you grant us permission to include your story in the digital archive and allow all visitors to the archive read it? You must grant us permission if you wish to add the story to our archive. Your email will not be made public. All other information, except for your name, if you chose to hide it, can be found by visitors to the archive. After submission, a link will be sent to the email address above that will allow you to edit or remove your contribution to the archive.
I accept these terms
This project is led by the Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies
Reischauer Institute Faculty and Staff providing additional support
Interactive Design and Development by Zeega.org
drag to add a cover image

Over the remainder of 2012 and into 2012, we will be introducing improvements to our current site, with particular attention to mapping and collection building. We welcome your suggestions and feedback.

The Digital Archive of Japan's 2011 Disasters is an evolving, collaborative space for citizens, researchers, and policy makers, and a site of shared memory for those most directly affected by these events. The digital archive is an advanced search engine for materials from all over the Web, individuals’ testimonials, tweets, and content from international partners who are building digital repositories about the disasters. The site not only facilitates searching of materials, but allows users to create their own curated collections on topics of interest to them. The collections can be shared publicly and add value to the items accessible through the archive.
This project is led by the Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies
Reischauer Institute Faculty and Staff providing additional support
Interactive Design and Development by Zeega.org
drag to add a cover image
Want to Register as a Group?
A group of users wishing to work together on collaborative projects should create a single account for the group using a shared ground username and group email address.

The Digital Archive of Japan’s 2011 Disasters (JDA) is an online portal to digital materials documenting the cascading series of natural and man-made disasters that began in Japan on March 11, 2011. Designed and maintained by the Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies at Harvard University, the JDA relies on the support of partner organizations around the world to supply digital contents, including websites, tweets, video, audio, news articles, and much more. The JDA does not store copies of the data; rather it seamlessly links to digital materials archived by partner projects, allowing you to search, view, and sort items across separate archives and collections in one interface.
This page provides information on how to use the archive interface for information retrieval. For more information on how to contribute to the archive yourself, please visit the
“How to Contribute to the Archive” page.

To search the archive, simply type text into the search box on the front page or the box that appears at the top of any other page and then either click the blue “go” button to the right of the search box or press the Enter/Return button on your keyboard.
To find documents predominantly in a certain language, simply type in that language. For example, typing English into the search box yields predominantly English search results, and typing Japanese into the search box yields predominantly Japanese search results.
To search for multiple keywords, place space between the words. It is also possible to use Boolean Operators for your search:

For all items except the testimonials and Tweets, the search engine will search through the title, description, and tags that were provided by the JDA staff, volunteers, and contributors. It will search through the full text of the testimonials and tweets.
When searching for tags, make sure to include quotes around phrases with more than one word, for instance: "cherry tree"
Without the quotes, the search engine will not return results.

To search for tags only, begin typing "tag" before your keywords. A popup in the search bar will allow you to select the "tag" field. To search for all fields, simply type in your keyword, or begin typing "text" and select it in the popup.

To search by media format, click “Browse” and select categories from the drop-down list on the right of the search bar. You can also click on “Advanced Search” to specify the media, location, time range, user, and search field on one screen.

The advanced search allows you to specify the keywords, media type, tags, user, dates, and location of geotagged items. To select multiple media formats, hold the Control key (Windows) or Apple key (Mac), then click on the preferred media. To specify the time range, click on the Start/End date fields. A calendar will pop up, allowing you to select specific dates. To limit by geographic location, hold the Shift key and drag your cursor around the map to create a box around the area. When you are ready to search, click on the "go" button at the bottom of the screen.

To search items by location, you can switch to the map screen and do a keyword search in the toolbar, or search by date and time by using the scroll bar directly below. You can also use the Advanced Search feature to limit the time and space of your search.

To add map layers, click on the gray icon on the right of the map. The “layers” tab will let you select additional types of information that you would like to display on the map, and the "legend" tab will tell you how this information is color-coded. Photographs, videos, tweets, and other data that contain geodata can all be linked in that way.
How to Contribute to the Archive

We need your help! The Digital Archive of Japan’s 2011 Disasters is an interactive resource that encourages users to help it grow and make it a valuable and lasting repository of digital information. You can contribute to the archive by adding new content, tagging or translating existing content, and creating and curating mini-exhibitions known as “Collections”.
This page describes how to contribute to the archive in more detail. For information on how to retrieve information from the archive, please visit the

You can submit relevant websites through by clicking on the “Add Website” link in the “Add to the Archive” menu. Please submit websites in any language that relate to the disasters and their aftermath. Fill out the form as completely as possible, including choosing the appropriate scope and frequency for our harvesting of the site. Scope refers to the depth of the harvesting - should we only harvest the front page, or the entire site? Frequency determines how often we harvest the site. For example, if the site is updated often, please choose a weekly or monthly frequency so we can keep our preservation of the website up to date. Upon submission, websites will be reviewed by an archivist before appearing in the archive.

You can add a testimonial to the archive by clicking on the “Add Testimonial” link in the “Add to the Archive” We are collecting testimonials from people affected by the disasters, whether they were in the disaster area at the time or elsewhere. Please submit your personal story to the archive. You can submit your testimonial anonymously if you wish, adding as much or as little biographical information as you feel comfortable with. Upon submission, testimonials will be reviewed by an archivist before appearing in the archive.

Our search is only as good as the information we have about the items in our archive. Tagging an item with keywords helps users find items in the archive that are relevant to their searches. Tags are especially valuable for items like photos, audio, and video, that do not have “full text” that can be searched. To add a tag, simply click on the red “add a tag” link in the item’s pop-up page, enter your tag, and press Enter/Return on your keyboard. Tags cannot be deleted once added, so please double check your spelling before entering. Please tag the items you find in your searches and help us improve our archive!

Every item in the archive can be translated by our users. To translate, click “edit translation” on the item’s pop-up page, and enter your translation into the box. It will then appear on the item’s page in the future. If a translation already exists and you would like to add to or fix it, click on “edit translation” to make and save your changes. Every translation contributed by our users adds value to the archive by allowing speakers of other languages to understand that item. Any item can be translated into any language, so please feel free to add a translation in your native language!

The “My Collection” feature allows users to organize materials discovered in the archive into a miniature “exhibition” of materials under a certain topic or theme. By curating a collection, you are establishing connections between the items according to your own criteria, and offering others a new perspective on the disaster. You might organize items by theme, place, time, or any other criteria you can imagine. You can also use the function to save items of personal interest to make it easier for you to access them later on.

While anyone can add materials to the archive, only registered users may create curated collections of the archived items. Registration is easy, simply sign into the site using the “Sign in” link in the upper right. Search for items of interest, then drag any item to the "my collection" box on the right.

If you click "Save Collection," then “Go to Collection” and click on the pencil icons, you will be able to edit the title and description of your collection. Your collection will stay up permanently, until you choose to delete it.

To edit or delete a collection, click on the pencil icon next to “Collection Description.” This will allow you to edit the title of your collection, edit the collection description, or delete the collection entirely.

It is possible to share individual collections with others by using the privacy setting. Click on the “Archive Settings” pencil to set the collection to “Public” or “Limited.” Choosing the “Public” setting means that other users will be able to see your collection. Choosing “Limited” means your collection will only be visible to you and those who have a link to the collection. It not show up in search results unless you change the settings.
